name: Deterioration of Furniture
short_description: Condition of furniture deteriorated due to ill-treatment by tenant

furniture_condition.cause: Ill-treatment by tenant or any other person residing

lodger_acts.included: Deterioration caused by lodger or subtenant
lodger_acts.tenant_liability: Tenant liable if failed to remove lodger after landlord's notice

evidence_required: Furniture inventory at start of tenancy

strong_cases: Furniture used inappropriately (e.g., standing on tables)
Pet damage to furniture (scratches, chewing, soiling)

high_probability: Detailed inventory with photos at start
Significant damage beyond wear and tear
low_probability: Damage is fair wear and tear

red_flags: Damage is normal wear and tear
tenant_defenses: Damage is fair wear and tear
Furniture was defective or poor quality
Tenant willing to repair or replace
notes: Ground 15 is DISCRETIONARY - applies only to furnished/part-furnished tenancies. Rarely used alone. Requires clear inventory and before/after evidence. Often combined with Ground 13 (property deterioration) or Ground 12 (breach). Deposit usually covers furniture damage so possession rare unless severe.
case_law: Holloway v Povey [1984] - Must distinguish ill-treatment from fair wear
Regalgrand v Dickerson [1997] - Inventory evidence crucial
Tormes Property v Landau [1971] - Deterioration must be proved
court_considerations: Was proper inventory conducted at start?
Is there clear evidence of deterioration?
Is damage beyond fair wear and tear?
Is furniture old or poor quality?

furniture_examples: Fabric wearing on frequently used sofa
Slight loosening of joints from normal use
not_fair_wear: Large tears or burns in upholstery

content: Detailed description of each furniture item
inventory_best_practice.timing: At check-in, ideally with independent inventory clerk
